results.title: Angels in America
results.creator_credit: Mike Nichols, Celia Costas and Home Box Office
results.brief_description: Caustic, funny, politically charged award winning television series, with an all-star cast set in New York City of the mid-1980s, when the horrific effects of AIDS was beginning to be realised. The narrative centres around numerous gay men some infected, some not and how it effects their lives and those of their families. Contains several celestial scenes, as well imaginary humorous settings that allow characters to ruminate and reflect upon their fate. Angels make appearances, the dead are raised and visions of the afterlife abound in this inventive, poetic and insightful work. Cast includes: Meryl Streep, Al Pacino, Mary Louise Parker, Jeffrey Wright and Emma Thompson. Directed by Mike Nichols and written by Tony Kushner, based on his Pulitzer winning play.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Nichols, Celia Costas and Home Box Office

results.title: Angels and acorns: Tasmanian 'colonial' stone carvings
results.creator_credit: Lindo Taylor, Norman Laird and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Illustrates the use of Australian sculpture in Tasmania from its earliest days to the end of the last century. Work of convict origin is shown including Ross Bridge with its notable sculptures and gargoyles. Photographer: Rodney Musch. Commentator: Bert Wicks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lindo Taylor, Norman Laird and Tasfilm Productions

results.title: Angelica Mesiti: The Calling interview
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery, ACMI and Ian Potter Cultural Trust
results.brief_description:
In this interview (filmed as part of activities associated with the ACMI Exhibition ‘Angelica Mesiti: The Calling’) the artist reflects on the structure, approach and the processes involved in creating the work.

‘The Calling’ is a three channel video installation that focuses on whistling languages, ancient forms of non-verbal communication which are still used in 2013 to communicate in isolated and difficult landscapes.

To conduct research for ‘The Calling’, artist Angelica Mesiti travelled to the village of Kuskoy in Northern Turkey, the island of La Gomera in The Canary Islands and the Island of Evia in Greece where whistling languages are still in use.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery, ACMI and Ian Potter Cultural Trust

results.title: Angele
results.brief_description:
Seduced and abandoned, Angele, a young naive peasant girl goes to Marseilles where she prostitutes herself in order to support her child. Angele’s father fetches her back to the farm, forcibly locking the girl and her newborn baby in his cellar. In Pagnol’s more Gionoesque works, a major theme is the Land and its relationship to Woman: both can be barren or fertile, unforgiving or kind, depending on circumstance and how one treats them. The earth’s fertility is often symbolised by spring water and traditionally baked bread; their absence indicates a world out of joint. Pagnol liked to celebrate the testing and renewal of human bonds; along with Jacques Feyder but in an entirely different, affirmative register, he is one of the French cinema’s great observer of the family.” Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992. ‘Angele’ was the first French film shot entirely on location with direct sound recording. It was hailed by Vittorio De Sica as an example for the Italian Neo-Realist School. See also: ‘La femme du boulanger’ directed by Marcel Pagnol (X000449).

Credits: Director, Marcel Pagnol ; writer, Marcel pagnol ; photography, Willy [Faktorovitch], Roger Ledru ; music, Vincent Scotto ; editor, Suzanne de Troeye ; art direction, Marius Brouquier.
Cast: Henri Poupon, Annie Toinon, Orane Demazis, Fernandel, Edouart Delmont, Jean Servais, Andrex, Charles Blavette, Blanche Poupon, Darcelys.

results.title: Angela and Angella
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Striving”.
Angela Bailey and Angella Taylor are both ranked in the world’s top ten in the 100 metres sprint. They are fierce rivals and this film shows us the girls’ gruelling daily regimen, their attitudes to one another and to international competition. At the Commonwealth Games of 1982, we watch the way in which their coach handles their triumphs and failures

results.title: Angela's ashes [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Allan Parker, Scott Rudin, David Brown and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: After immigrating to America, young Frank and his family move back to Limerick following the death of his infant sister. The family is forced to live in the slums of Ireland, with conditions being much worse than they were in America. His Northern Irish father, Malachy, has difficulty finding work because of his former loyalty to the IRA, and what little money he earns, he drinks away, leaving Frank, his mother Angela, and his young brother to scrounge for coal and beg for food and clothing. Determined to escape the poverty, illness, and death that surrounds him in Ireland, Frank dreams of returning to America. Cast includes Emily Watson and Robert Carlyle. Based on the Pulitzer Prize winning autobiography by Frank McCourt.

results.title: Angel on my shoulder
results.creator_credit: Archie Mayo and Charles R. Rogers
results.brief_description: Film Noir classic wherein the devil promises leniency to a dead gangster if he will return to earth and take over the body of a judge who is stamping out evil. Stars Claude Rains, Paul Muni and Anne Baxter.

results.title: Angel of vengeance = Ms.45
results.creator_credit: Abel Ferrara, Navaron Films and Rochelle Films
results.brief_description: Abel Ferrara’s (‘Bad Lieutenant’, ‘King of New York’, ‘Driller Killer’) foray into the revenge fantasy genre is an often unnerving film which owes a lot to Roman Polanski’s disturbing tale of sexual terror, ‘Repulsion’. Set in the rough garment district of New York, ‘Angel of Vengeance’ follows the gradual descent into madness of Thana (Zoe Tamerlis), a mute seamstress who snaps after she is raped twice in one day. Her reaction to it plays like a strange form of liberation, as the once timid seamstress proceeds to off some of the more sleazier male citizens of New York city. Ferrara sprinkles this unusual and stylish low budget film with dark comic moments, eccentric characters (like Thana’s weird landlady played by Editta Sherman), and its slow motion climax is a beautiful and surreal piece of filmmaking. Cast includes Albert Sinkys, Darlene Stuto, Helen McGara, Nike Zachmanoglou.

results.title: Angel in the house
results.brief_description: The film takes as its theme an essay by Virginia Woolf written in 1927. In the essay Virginia Woolf talks about women writers and the psychological and social barriers to their creativity and their self-confidence. In 1977, the film’s protagonist Lily Ramsey is an aspiring writer, and an admirer of Virginia Woolf. In an attempt to complete her first novel, she takes a break from her job in London and goes home to the small seaside town where her family still lives. However, for Lily home is not simply a peaceful place to write, but part of the experience which she brings to bear on her writing.

results.title: Angel food
results.creator_credit: Julia Bourke, Paul Fletcher, Anne Shenfield, Robert Stephenson and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Animated film that charts the short-lived adventures of an intrepid strawberry as it evades a variety of kitchen hazards - including vicious utensils, distraction by a Busby Berkeley-style fruit mambo, and a seductive but ultimately deadly pot of melted chocolate - to fulfill its quest to sit atop a decadent whipped cream and meringue dessert. “A glossy tale with a sticky end.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julia Bourke, Paul Fletcher, Anne Shenfield, Robert Stephenson and Victorian College of the Arts
